snippet: There will be no legal precedent from a judge's ordering a convicted child abuser last year to use a birth control implant as a condition of probation, because a state appeals court has ruled that the order is now moot.   The defendant, Darlene Jo...
lead_paragraph: There will be no legal precedent from a judge's ordering a convicted child abuser last year to use a birth control implant as a condition of probation, because a state appeals court has ruled that the order is now moot. The defendant, Darlene Johnson, was sentenced to prison last month for using cocaine, which violated another condition of her probation for child abuse. So the issue of whether she can be forced to use a birth control device is no longer relevant, the Fifth District Court of Appeal decided Monday in dismissing the case at her lawyer's request.

headline.main: BIRTH CURB ORDER IS DECLARED MOOT
